Graphical abstract Glycerol, a by-product of biodiesel industry, could be utilized for the production of hydrogen via steam reforming. In the present work, three Ru-based catalysts, namely Ru/Al2O3, Ru/Β2Ο3-Al2O3 and Ru/MgO-Al2O3, have been studied regarding their physicochemical and catalytic properties for the title reaction. N2 adsorption-desorption, powder XRD, CO Adsorption, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, TPR, TEM and SEM-EDS were employed to investigate the textural and structural characteristics of the catalysts. Quantitative assessment of the carbonaceous deposits, formed under reaction conditions, was performed using TPH and TPO methods The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts for the glycerol steam reforming reaction has been investigated in a fixed bed plug flow reactor using a feed of water/glycerol at a molar ratio of 20:1 at 400, 500 and 600°C. Results show that at the low reaction temperature (400°C), the support has a determining role on the catalytic performance, the selectivity to various oxygenates depending on the acid-base properties of the catalyst. At higher temperature (600°C) metal activity dominates, H2 and CO2 being the main reaction products. Keywords Glycerol Steam reforming Ru/Al2O3 catalysts B2O3 MgO Carbon formation 1 Introduction During the last century, energy generation has been based on fossil fuels. Nowadays, sustainability dictates the exploration of alternative paths, turning to renewables which have lower carbon footprint. In this respect, different energy sources have been considered, such as wind, solar, water, geothermal and biomass. Designing of efficient energy systems must take into account transformation and conversion processes, delivery, production of the anticipated effect, and satisfactory handling of waste and pollutants [1,2]. An intelligent management should integrate all energy resources and vectors, such as electricity, heat, hydrogen, bio- and non-bio-fuels [1]. Hydrogen is considered as a promising energy vector and has received substantial attention in policy priorities in view of the so called “Hydrogen Economy” [2–4]. It is regarded as a clean energy carrier, particularly for the transportation sector and fuel cell electric vehicles [4]. The development of cost-effective production processes, with immediate environmental benefits, is prerequisite for short-term introduction of H2-based energy technologies [3,5]. Today, hydrogen is manufactured primarily via the steam reforming of natural gas or other hydrocarbons, a well-established and vastly used method [3]. However, its production from fossil fuels has high well-to-wheel CO2 emissions, with concomitant financial and environmental drawbacks, which hinder its application as a clean energy carrier. Thus, several alternative processes have been proposed, based on renewables such aselectrolysis using electricity from renewable sources (wind, solar, biomass, etc.). Biomass as raw material has neutral carbon effect, whereas different processes may be applied to generate hydrogen (pyrolysis, gasification, or reforming). Organic industrial by-products or wastes look particularly appealing for this purpose. In this context, crude glycerol is an interesting candidate. Glycerol is the main by-product of biodiesel manufacturing from vegetable oils and fats transesterification, accounting for ca. 10wt% of feedstock. The growth of biodiesel industry creates surplus of glycerol [6]. In an effort to decrease biodiesel production costs and wastes disposal, several uses have been proposed for this glycerol fraction [6–8]. Among these, reforming processes seem particularly attractive as no water separation is necessary and, depending on operating conditions, high hydrogen yields can be obtained [6,8–18]. Steam reforming of glycerol (SRG) presents a significant advantage, compared to steam reforming of methanol or ethanol, due to its high hydrogen yield: 7mol of hydrogen are produced per mol of glycerol as per the reaction stoichiometry (Eq. (1)). However, thermodynamic analysis sets the upper limit to 6-6.2mol of hydrogen per mol of glycerol, which can be achieved by applying temperatures higher than 630° C, water-rich feed (steam to glycerol (S/G) molar ratio higher than 9:1) and atmospheric pressure [19,20]. SRG is considered as the combination of two main reactions, namely glycerol decomposition (Eq. (2)) and water-gas shift (WGS, Eq. (3)): (1) C 3 O 3 H 8 + 3 H 2 O ↔ 3CO 2 + 7 H 2 Δ H 0 = 128 kJ/mol (2) C 3 O 3 H 8 ↔ 3CO + 4 H 2 Δ H 0 = 245 kJ/mol (3) CO + H 2 O ↔ CO 2 + H 2 Δ H 0 = − 41 kJ/mol Decomposition of glycerol follows a complicated reaction network, involving several parallel and consecutive steps such as dehydration, dehydrogenation/hydrogenation, isomerisation, polymerization of reaction intermediates, as well as CC and CO bond cleavage [16,21,22]. Glycerol decomposes at temperatures higher than 300°C even in the absence of a catalyst [18]. Metal oxides can promote SRG to some extend, increasing conversion to gaseous products with the increase of surface basicity [18]. Nevertheless, H2 yield obtained over pristine metal oxides is negligible [18]. Supported nickel catalysts are considered to be suitable for SRG as they are active and cost effective. However, they are not stable with time-on-stream and deactivate under reaction conditions, mainly due to carbon deposition [12,13,18,21,23,24]. Despite being more expensive, noble metals are commonly used for reforming reactions as these are highly active and less susceptible to carbon formation [21,23,25]. Ruthenium appears to be a promising option for glycerol conversion to H2, as it is the least expensive of noble metals and it exhibits remarkable reforming activity [6,17]. However, the nature of the support, the catalyst composition, and the synthesis parameters seem to have an important effect on the catalytic performance. SRG was studied by Hirai et al. [26] at 600°C over a number of 0.5wt% Ru-based catalysts. These were prepared via conventional impregnation method of Y2O3, ZrO2, CeO2, La2O3, SiO2, MgO, and Al2O3 supports. The highest glycerol conversion and H2 yield were obtained over Y2O3-and ZrO2-supported catalysts, whereas Ru/SiO2, Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/MgO exhibited poor catalytic performance [26]. The reasons for the observed results were not specified as physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts were not provided [26]. For Ru/Y2O3, the increase of Ru loading up to 3wt% resulted in higher glycerol conversion, hydrogen yield and carbon dioxide selectivity [26]. Kim and Lee [27] used two series of catalysts, monometallic 1.0wt% Ru and bimetallic Ru-Me (Me=Fe, Co, Ni, and Mo), supported on Al2O3, Y2O3, and Ce0.5Zr0.5O2. The presence of the second metal had limited impact but the type of support affected catalytic properties markedly. Glycerol conversion turnover rate and H2 selectivity were higher and coking was lower over Ru/Y2O3 and Ru/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 catalysts. The improved performance was attributed to the facilitation of the WGS reaction [27]. Nevertheless, these catalysts deactivated within a few hours, due to metal sintering [27]. Commercial alumina ceramic foam monolith was applied as support by Adhikari et al. [28] for the synthesis of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts with 2.5wt% Ru loading. Interestingly, the catalysts were used after calcination in air without reduction. Glycerol conversion and H2 selectivity over Ru/Al2O3 were poorer than those reported in other studies for reduced catalysts, although similar or more favorable reaction conditions were applied by Adhikari et al. [28]. In the presence of ceria catalytic performance was improved [28]. In addition to the nature of the support and synthesis parameters, the performance Ru-based catalysts is also depended on reaction conditions. Higher temperatures, higher water/glycerol ratios in feed and longer contact time seem to enhance glycerol conversion and H2 yield and inhibit coking [29,30]. Summarizing, literature reports show that catalyst composition and reaction conditions are greatly influencing the outcome of the SRG reaction, although the reasons are not always clear. In the present work, glycerol steam reforming reaction has been investigated over Ru/Al2O3 catalysts promoted with Β2Ο3 or MgO, i.e. a more acidic and a more basic oxide than alumina, respectively. γ-Al2O3 has been selected as support because of its good textural properties and thermal and mechanical stability. In addition, having certain acidity, γ-Al2O3 is active for acid-base catalyzed reactions such as dehydration, isomerization and polymerization, which take place during glycerol reforming. Still, acidity must be tuned to promote the desired reactions, hindering cracking and carbon formation. The addition of B2O3 aims at changing the acidity of Al2O3 by creating new weaker acidic sites [31]. Therefore, it should favor the reaction paths that involve dehydration steps but not steps that are responsible for coking. On the other hand, MgO-Al2O3 supports exhibit more basic properties minimizing coke formation [30,32]. Catalysts have been investigated as regards the textural and structural characteristics and the catalytic performance for SRG reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation A commercial γ-Al2O3 was used as support. The Ru precursor was ruthenium (III) nitrosylnitrate (Ru(NO)(NO3)3), provided as a Ru=1.5% w/v solution (Alfa Aesar). In all cases, the nominal metal loading was 5wt% Ru in the reduced catalyst. For the Ru/Al2O3 (RuAl) catalyst, alumina was dispersed in a diluted aqueous solution of the ruthenium precursor and remained under stirring for one hour, followed by water evaporation and drying overnight at 90°C. Then, RuAl catalyst was reduced under flowing H2 at 200°C for 2h and at 350°C for 2h. The Ru/B2O3-Al2O3 (RuBAl) catalyst was synthesized by wet co–impregnation using the aqueous solution of Ru(NO)(NO3)3 and Η3ΒΟ3. Drying and H2-reduction were performed following the same procedure used for the unmodified catalyst. Ru/MgO-Al2O3 (RuMgAl) catalyst was prepared in two steps. In the first step, MgO was introduced by wet impregnation of alumina with an aqueous solution of Mg(NO3)2*6H2O, followed by water evaporation and drying at 90°C overnight. The dried binary support MgO-Al2O3 was submitted to temperature programmed calcination (10°C/min) up to 900°C. The calcination at this temperature continued for 16h. In the second step, ruthenium precursor was introduced as in RuAl catalyst. The prepared materials, their notation and nominal compositions are shown in Table 1 . 2.2 Characterization techniques Textural properties were calculated based on the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C using a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 apparatus. Specific surface areas (SSA) and porosity were calculated by the standard B.E.T. and B.J.H methods, respectively, within the nitrogen relative pressure range of 0.06< P/P0 <0.20. X-ray diffractograms of the catalysts were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15418nm) and operating at 40kV and 40mA, in the angle range 10°<2θ<85°, with a step size of 0.015° and a scan speed of 0.3s/step. Phase identification was based on JCPDF data files. The average size of metal crystallites was calculated following the Scherrer equation. Ru dispersion was measured by CO pulse chemisorption, employing an automated chemisorption analysis apparatus (Sorptomatic 1900, Fisons Instruments). The pre-reduced catalyst sample (ca 1.000g) was pretreated as follows: (a) dynamic vacuum at 250°C for 1h; (b) reduction with H2 (1bar) at 250°C for 1h; (c) evacuation for 30min at 250°C; and (d) cooling down to the chemisorption temperature (RT) under vacuum. CO uptake at monolayer coverage of the metal particles was obtained by extrapolation of the linear portion of the adsorption isotherm to zero pressure. The exposed metal surface area was calculated assuming a CO: metal stoichiometry of 1:1. The mean crystallite size of the dispersed metal was estimated assuming spherical particles from the equation [33]: d * D = M * 6 * ρ s i t e ρ m e t a l * N where d is the particle size of Ru, D is the dispersion, M is the molecular mass (Ru=101g/mol), ρsite is number of Ru atoms per nm2 (16.3 Ru atoms/nm2), ρmetal is the metal density (Ru 12.3g/cm3), and N is the Avogadro number (6.022×1023 atoms/mol). Surface acidity was estimated by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). All samples were pre-reduced in order to evaluate their acidity at a similar state as they meet the reactant stream. 100mg of the pre-reduced catalyst (as described previously) were reduced in situ under a stream of pure H2 (30mL/min) at 400°C for 30min and then cooled to RT under a flow of He (30mL/min) to remove adsorbed H2. Next, a stream of NH3/He mixture was introduced in the reactor for 1h and then switched to He (30mL/min) to remove ammonia physically adsorbed on the catalyst surface. When the signals, monitored by an MS detector (FL-9496 Balzers), were stabilized, temperature was increased from RT to 750°C at a rate of 10°C/min. Signal calibration was performed using known quantities of ammonia to the mass spectrometer. Surface basicity was quantified by Temperature-Programmed Desorption of adsorbed CO2 (CO2-TPD). The pre-treatment procedure was exactly the same with that followed for NH3-TPD. After cooling down to RT under a flow of He (30mL/min) to remove adsorbed H2, a stream of 10% CO2/He mixture was introduced for 30min. TPD was performed in the same way as that followed for NH3-TPD. Reducibility of catalysts was studied by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) with hydrogen. After drying, the catalysts were not calcined but reduced in pure hydrogen (see catalysts’ preparation). In order to study their reducibility, the dried materials were submitted to smooth thermal treatment in air, just to decompose the nitrosyl nitrate salt. The temperature was increased gradually as follows: From RT to 120°C temperature increased by 2°C/min. At 120°C, the material was kept for 30min to remove moisture and then temperature increased up to 240°C with the same rate (2°C/min). At 240°C the catalyst remained for 60min before reduction. 250mg of the material, previously dried at 120°C was heated under a stream of 10% H2/Ar (40mL/min) from RT to 800°C, with a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. More details regarding TPR procedure can be found in a previous work [18]. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) micrographs were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained in a JEOL 6300 microscope, equipped with an Oxford energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic performance for the steam reforming of glycerol was evaluated using a fixed bed plug-flow reactor, operating at atmospheric pressure. As described in Section 2.1, after drying catalysts were not calcined but reduced. 200mg of the pre-reduced catalyst (particle size 180–250μm) were further reduced in situ under a stream of H2 (50mL/min), while temperature was increasing following a ramp of 10°C/min, from RT to 550°C, where it was kept for 2h. Then, the reactor was purged with helium for 15min and temperature was increased to the desired test temperature where the reaction feed was introduced into the catalyst bed. The feed was prepared as follows: A 20:80wt% glycerol/water solution, S/G molar ratio equal to 20, is kept in a container under continuous stirring at room temperature. It was introduced into the evaporator using an HPLC pump. At the same time an Ar/He mixture (1:40), controlled by two separate mass flow controllers, was introduced into the evaporator from another inlet. The evaporator outlet, consisting of 20% Ηe, 1% Ar, 75% Η2Ο and 4% glycerol, at W/F=1.05mgminmL−1, was fed into the reactor. Evaporator and tubing were held at 350°C in order to make sure that glycerol is completely in the gas phase. Firstly, γ-Al2O3 and Ru/Al2O3 catalyst were tested for their catalytic activity and selectivity in the temperature range of 400–800°C, at steady state conditions for each temperature. Taking into consideration the obtained results, the catalysts were then evaluated in tests that were performed for exactly 3h, at temperatures of 400, 500 and 600°C, using a fresh catalyst sample at each temperature. Activation was performed as described above. Feed and gas-phase reaction products were analysed by 3 gas chromatographs: a) a Shimadzu GC-8A, equipped with a packed Carbosieve SII column and a TCD detector, b) a Shimadzu GC-9A equipped with a packed Porapak Q column and an FID detector and c) a Shimadzu GC-14Α with a packed Carboxen 1000 column and a TCD detector. A cold trap was used for the condensation of the liquid products at the reactor exit before entering the gas chromatograph system. The condensed liquids were analysed using GC–MS system (Hewlett-Packard 6890-HP 5973) with a capillary column (HP-INNOWax). The analysis procedure is described in detail elsewhere [18]. The total glycerol conversion (Xtot) and the glycerol conversion to gaseous products (Xgas) were calculated with the use of the following the equations: (4) X t o t = [ G l y c e r o l ] i n − [ G l y c e r o l ] o u t [ G l y c e r o l ] i n × 100 (5) X g a s = [ t o t a l C a r b o n ] o u t , g a s [ G l y c e r o l ] i n × 100 (6) [ t o t a l C a r b o n ] o u t , g a s = ∑ [ P 1 i ] ] 3 + 2 × ∑ [ P 2 i ] 3 + ∑ [ P 3 i ] where P1i , P2i and P3i , represent the product i that contains one, two or three carbon atom(s) in the molecule, respectively. Yields of products were calculated as follows: (7) Y P 1 i = [ P 1 i ] 3 × [ g l y c e r o l ] i n × 100 f o r 1 C c o n t a i n i n g m o l e c u l e s (8) Y P 2 i = 2 × [ P 2 i ] 3 × [ g l y c e r o l ] i n × 100 f o r 2 C c o n t a i n i n g m o l e c u l e s (9) Y P 3 i = [ P 3 i ] [ g l y c e r o l ] i n × 100 f o r 3 C c o n t a i n i n g m o l e c u l e s (10) ϒ H 2 = [ H 2 ] 7 × [ g l y c e r o l ] i n × 100 2.4 Analysis of carbonaceous deposits The carbonaceous deposits on the spent catalysts were measured by Temperature Programmed Hydrogenation (TPH) followed by Temperature Programmed Oxidation (TPO). At the end of the 3 h-long catalytic test, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature under a flow of He (15 mLmin−1) to remove the unconverted reactants and products from the catalyst surface, reactor and tubing. A sample of the used catalyst was collected, dried overnight at 120°C and then stored in a desiccator. A weighted amount of the sample was placed in the reactor used for TPH/TPO experiments and purged with He at RT. The temperature was then increased from RT to 750°C at a rate of 10°C/min under a reductive gas mixture of 6% H2/He (30mL/min) at atmospheric pressure. Reaction products were monitored with a mass spectrometer (FL-9496 Balzers) connected on-line at the reactor effluent. Temperature was kept at 750°C until the methane signal reached the baseline. Then, the sample was cooled down to RT and TPO was conducted under a flow of 6% O2/He (30mL/min), following the same procedure. The MS detector was calibrated with the use of H2, O2, CO, CO2 and CH4 (in He) gas mixtures of known concentration. The TPH and TPO signals were continuously monitored and integrated to calculate the total amount of carbonaceous deposits. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of catalytic materials 3.1.1 Textural properties The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms obtained for the RuAl catalyst show that its textural properties do not differ significantly from those of the γ-Al2O3 support, being both mesoporous materials with cylindrical type of pores. A bimodal pore size distribution is observed for RuAl (Fig. S1). RuBAl has similar textural properties, (Table 1 and Fig. S1). This indicates that B2O3 loading and introduction method has no significant effect on the textural properties of RuBAl, in agreement with previous results on NiB(x)/Al2O3 catalysts [18,34]. Differences in texture are more pronounced for the RuMgAl catalyst, which has a significantly lower SSA, a higher average pore diameter and a much smaller pore volume, as compared with the other Ru catalysts (Table 1). Taking into account that the textural properties of the catalysts are mainly due to γ-Al2O3, the lower SSA of RuMgAl can be attributed, at least in part, to its lower alumina content (78.2%) compared to RuAl (95%) and RuBAl (93.4%). Additional plausible reasons for the relatively low SSA of the RuMgAl catalyst include the blockage of the smaller mesopores of alumina and/or sintering during the calcination of the MgO/γ-Al2O3 support. Pore size distribution confirms these hypotheses as small pores are practically eliminated (Fig. S1). 3.1.2 Crystalline phases and metal dispersion The XR-diffractograms of the reduced Ru-catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . The XRD pattern of reduced RuAl is almost identical to that of γ-Al2O3 The Ruo peaks are hardly detectable for this sample, indicating very good dispersion of ruthenium phase. In contrast to RuAl, the XRD pattern of the RuBAl catalyst is characterized by sharp and intense Ruo peaks (Fig. 1). Comparison with the unmodified sample shows that the boron oxide deteriorates the dispersion of ruthenium, contrary to what observed for NiO/B2O3-Al2O3 catalysts [18,34]. As expected, no boron containing phases can be detected. Boron oxides are difficult to crystallize, forming amorphous glass-like phases [34]. The XRD pattern of RuMgAl shows interesting alterations, compared to the other two samples (Fig. 1). Reflection peaks due to alumina are shifted towards smaller angles, indicating the formation of a new phase. The transition of γ-Al2O3 to another purely alumina phase such as δ-Al2O3 or α-Al2O3, during the high temperature calcination of MgO-Al2O3 support, has been considered. However, no match could be found based on the JCPDS data files. In contrast, MgAl2O4 (JCPDS 21-1152) has been identified. The formation of this oxide has been reported after calcination of MgO-Al2O3 catalysts at 900°C for several hours (>12h) [32,35]. This is accompanied by a progressive decrease of SSA, in line with the deterioration of the textural properties observed for RuMgAl (Table 1). Reflections due to ruthenium overlap with those of MgAl2O4 with the exception of the peak at 2θ=42.4°. Thus, the average size of the metal particles was estimated using the Scherrer equation and the reflection peak at 2θ=42.4°. For the reduced RuAl catalyst this was not possible because of the low intensity of the peak. The size of Ru0 crystallites has been estimated to be 14.1±0.6nm for RuBAl and 16.9±0.5nm for RuMgAl (Table 2 ). Ru dispersion and average particle size was also measured by CO chemisorption and results are included in Table 2. Differences in Ru dispersion are more clear. Although values obtained by the two methods are not the same, the trend is identical. The presence of the second oxide does not seem to improve ruthenium dispersion. Previous studies on Ru/Al2O3 catalysts have revealed that metal dispersion and even metal particles’ morphology are sensitive to many parameters, including precursor materials and thermal treatment applied [36]. 3.1.3 Surface acidity and basicity At low reaction temperatures, the acid-base properties of the catalyst can determine the catalytic behavior [18]. The acidity has been investigated via NH3 adsorption-desorption on reduced Ru-catalysts and the NH3-TPD profiles are given in Fig. 2 A. Only NH3 could be detected during TPD, showing that adsorption and desorption of ammonia take place molecularly. For all catalysts, desorption becomes important above 60°C and the first peak is observed between 90 and 115°C, corresponding to the weaker acid sites. Desorption continues at higher temperatures, but most of the adsorbed ammonia is released before 500°C, indicating the presence of mainly weak/medium acid sites. The NH3-TPD profile of the reduced RuAl is quite similar to that reported by Vasiliadou et al. [37], although in their work the catalyst is studied after calcination. It can be concluded that reduction does not change considerably the nature of acid sites. The total amount of desorbed ammonia (calculated from signal integration and expressed per gram of catalyst) decreases following the order RuBAl > RuAl > RuMgAl (Fig. 2 A inset). As it can be observed and in accordance with other studies [18 and references therein,31], the acidity of the catalyst increases in the presence of B2O3. On the contrary, the presence of a basic oxide such as MgO and the formation of MgAl2O4 suppress the acidity of the reduced RuMgAl catalyst. The CO2-TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 2 B. Desorption of CO2 starts at about 50°C for the RuAl catalyst, goes through a maximum at 72°C and continues up to 250°C. In the presence of boron oxide, the strength of CO2 adsorption sites decreases drastically, which is indicated by the fact that desorption is almost completed at 120°C. The CO2-TPD profile of RuMgAl shows higher amount of CO2 desorbed whereas desorption takes place at higher temperatures than in the case of the other two catalysts. As expected, addition of MgO increases both the number and the strength of basic sites. Magnesium aluminate, present in RuMgAl, is more basic than alumina [38]. The significance of the increase in basicity is more obvious when the total amount of desorbed CO2 (calculated from signal integration) is expressed per unit surface area (Fig. 2 B inset). 3.1.4 Reducibility H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 3 . For all catalysts, the most important hydrogen consumption occurs between 200 and 300°C. The main peak is observed at 251°C for RuAl, at 254°C for RuBAl and at 261°C for RuMgAl, forming a decaying tail up to 450°C. Profiles of RuAl and RuBAl exhibit a shoulder at lower temperature, at about 203°C and 221°C respectively. These H2-TPR profiles are typical for supported Ru-based catalysts. The main peak is attributed to the reduction of RuO2 to metallic Ru [37,39,40]. Unsupported RuO2 or Ru precursor salts are reported to reduce at temperatures bellow 220°C [40,41]. Shift to higher temperatures is attributed to higher interaction of oxide species with the support [37,40] or even dissolution of Ru in the spinel lattice, as implied by Bossola et al. [40] in the case of Ru/MgO-Al2O3 catalysts. The origin of the shoulder at lower temperature is not clear. It has been suggested to be due to the reduction of well dispersed RuOx species [37,42], different ruthenium species, [39] or even the removal of ions of the precursor salt [43]. The latter could be quite possible in our case, as the catalysts have been submitted to a mild thermal treatment before H2-TPR. The amount of hydrogen consumed (Fig. 3 inset) is higher than that required for the complete reduction of RuO2 (assuming that this is the main ruthenium phase in all catalysts). This excess in hydrogen consumption could be due to the removal of other ions of the precursor salt. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of the bare γ-Al2O3 support and the RuAl catalyst was studied in the temperature range of 400–800°C and results obtained are shown in Fig. 4 . Alumina can convert glycerol to gaseous products at temperatures higher than 600°C, but hydrogen yield does not exceed 20% even at 800°C. The addition of Ru improves significantly the catalytic activity. Over RuAl, conversion to gaseous products reaches almost 100% at 600°C. At this temperature hydrogen yield is maximized (70%), whereas at higher temperatures hydrogen production decreases. This is due to the equilibrium of the WGS reaction (Eq. (3)), as confirmed by the increase of CO yield and the decrease of CO2 yield (Fig. S2). Further catalytic tests were performed for a period of 3h at 400, 500 and 600°C over RuAl, RuBAl and RuMgAl, using a fresh catalyst sample each time, in order to estimate coking rate at each temperature. Total glycerol conversion (in the liquid and gas phase) was 99–100% over RuAl and RuBAl catalysts even at 400°C. RuMgAl was found to be less active, with total conversion reaching 88% at 600°C. Conversion of glycerol to gas-phase products (Xgas) at 400°C varies between 18% and 35%, the higher activity exhibited by RuAl (Fig. 5 ). Increase of temperature favors the formation of gas-phase products in a manner that depends on catalyst composition. At 600°C, Xgas is 93% over RuAl and 85% over RuBAl, but only 57% over RuMgAl. The inferior performance of RuMgAl may be attributed to its lower acidity and higher basicity (Fig. 2) and/or the smaller number of active sites, as this catalyst has smaller SSA (Table 1) and larger Ru particles (Table 2). In addition, the poorer dispersion of Ru on MgO-modified Al2O3 carrier implies also reduced interfacial area between Ru metal and carrier. Since reaction steps may be taking place at the interface, this would manifest itself as reduced conversion. The latter interception is in accordance with the results of Wang et al. [44]. On the other hand, Vasiliadou et al. [37] did not find any particular effect of Ru dispersion on activity, acidity of the catalyst determining glycerol hydrogenolysis. Hydrogen yield was found to follow the exact same trends as conversion to gaseous products. Maximum hydrogen yield (∼69%) was attained over RuAl at 500°C and RuBAl at 600°C (Fig. 6 ). These values correspond to 4.8mol of hydrogen produced per mol glycerol in the feed, in accordance with the thermodynamic predictions [20]. CO2 yields is also high (>82%), whereas CO yield is very low (<15%) (Fig. 6). Methane yield was less than 1% in all studied cases, whereas only traces of ethane, ethylene or propene could be detected at lower temperatures. The liquid fraction of glycerol reformation products contains a significant variety of compounds. Qualitative analysis, of the liquid products formed over Ru/Al2O3 catalysts at 400°C, shows that acrolein (2-propenal), acetol (1-hydroxy-2-propanone) and acetaldehyde (ethanal) are the main oxygenated products, followed by allyl alcohol, acetic acid, acetone, propanal,etc. Compounds with more than three carbons were also observed: phenol, cyclo-pentenones (e.g, 2-hydroxy-3-methyl-2-cyclopenten-1-one), dioxolanes (e.g. 4-hydroxymethyl-2-methyl-1,3-dioxolane) and dioxanes (e.g. 5-hydroxy-2-methyl-1,3-dioxane) and some others in lower concentrations. Acetol and acrolein are formed following dehydration steps [18,21]. The activation of a terminal OH group of glycerol and the subsequent subtraction of one molecule of water result in the production of acetol [21,45], while the activation of a secondary hydroxy group and the successive elimination of two molecules of water form acrolein [18,45]. Acetaldehyde formation follows a CC bond cleavage and is accompanied by production of hydrogen and CO [21]. Metal oxides are known to catalyze these reactions [18,45–48]. Glycerol dehydration to acrolein is catalyzed by acid solids, exhibiting mainly Brönsted acidity, although there is no general agreement on the nature of the acid sites [45,47,48]. The formation of acetol is also related to acid sites, which are suggested to be of Brönsted type [49] or Lewis type or a combination of basic surface-OH groups and acid–base pair sites as well [45,50]. Hernandez at al. [46] reported that dehydration to acetol can also take place over basic materials. In a previous study, we have shown that acrolein formation increases with the increase of surface acidity of modified Ni/Al2O3 catalysts [18]. On the other hand, these compounds possess a very active carbonyl group which can form 1,3-dioxanes and 1,3-dioxolanes over a Brönsted or a Lewis acid catalyst, explaining the presence of the latter in the liquid fraction. Quantitative analysis was focused on acrolein, acetol and acetaldehyde, as these are the main liquid products. Remarkable differentiations have been observed between the three catalysts (Fig. 7 ). At 400°C, RuAl and RuBAl have comparable total glycerol conversion and yields of acrolein (∼21%) and acetaldehyde (∼7%). Acetol production is somewhat higher over RuBAl (4.5%) as compared to RuAl (3.2%). However, there are differences in the rest of the products; more hydrogen and gas-phase products are obtained over RuAl whereas compounds with more than three carbon atoms (such as phenol or cyclo-pentenones) were detected in higher amounts over RuBAl. These differences may be attributed to the different acid–base properties (Fig. 2). Alumina possesses mainly Lewis acidity whereas B2O3-Al2O3 materials have higher acidity (mainly of Brönsted type) related to the boron content [31,51]. This fact indicates that RuAl is more active as regards CC bond dissociation and WGS reaction, while condensation and polymerization are enhanced over the more acidic RuBAl, in accordance with literature reports [45,48]. RuMgAl catalyst exhibits a very different selectivity to oxygenate products, forming more acetaldehyde and much less acrolein than the other two samples. As glycerol conversion is lower over this catalyst, yields of oxygenates are also lower (Fig. 7), being 11% of acetaldehyde and 9% of acrolein at 400°C. The production of oxygenates decreases with the increase of temperature but not to the same extent (Fig. S3). Over RuAl, acrolein, acetol and acetaldehyde yields are negligible at higher temperatures, while over RuBA, acrolein is still the main dehydration product at 500°C, but at lower quantities than at 400°C. These compounds are still observed even at 600°C when RuMgAl is used (Fig. S3). The poor catalytic performance of this catalyst may be due to a combination of various reasons. One reason may be the lower number of metal active sites, as dispersion of ruthenium on the surface of this catalyst is poorer (Table 2). Another possible reason is the partial coverage of the Ru particles by the support, a phenomenon reported for a Ru/MgAl2O4 catalyst [52]. Thus, catalytic behaviour is determined by the properties of the basic support, i.e. the lower glycerol conversion to gas-phase products and the formation of oxygenate products even at 600°C. Another point worth noting is the highest acetaldehyde yield obtained by this catalyst. It has been suggested that acetaldehyde may originate from a different path than acetol [53] probably from retro-aldol reactions catalyzed by strong basic sites [22,46]. Our results support this suggestion. Summarizing catalytic tests, RuAl catalyst is more active towards the formation of gas-phase products at lower temperatures, with maximum hydrogen yield at 500°C. The presence of B2O3 favours dehydration of glycerol and production of oxygenates at lower temperatures. At 600°C, RuBAl catalyst yields the same quantity of hydrogen as RuAl at 500°C. RuMgAl is less active regarding dehydration but also gasification reactions in the whole temperature range. In general, the results of the present work are in agreement with similar studies reported in the literature as they show that increase of temperature and the high steam/glycerol ratio used enhance the conversion of glycerol to gas-phase products, increase the yield of H2 and suppress methanation reactions [27–30]. However, it is difficult to make a more detailed comparison as catalyst pre-treatment and reaction conditions are crucial factors for catalytic efficiency. Much higher glycerol conversion to gaseous products and hydrogen yield are obtained at low temperatures (400–600°C) over the non-calcined but reduced RuAl catalyst of the present study than those reported by Adhikari et al. [28] over the calcined and non-reduced Ru/Al2O3 catalyst at higher temperatures (700–900°C). RuAl catalyst is also less selective towards CO, whereas CH4 is practically negligible, contrary to the results of Adhikari et al. [28]. Kim and Lee [27] investigated the performance of a Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, calcined and then reduced in situ. These authors reported that Ru/Al2O3 catalyst produced large amounts of CO and C1 C2 hydrocarbons and had low H2 selectivity, due to lower reforming and WGS activity compared to the Ru/Y2O3 and Ru/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 catalysts in the same study [27]. On the contrary, in the present study, CO formation and WGS activity is high even at 600°C. Gallo et al. [30] investigated the performance of a 0.6wt% Ru/MgAlO catalyst, calcined, reduced and tested under reaction conditions similar to the present study. At low glycerol concentrations and reaction temperatures (400 and 500°C), glycerol conversion is low but selectivity to hydrogen is high. Gallo et al. [30] report the absence of thermal decomposition of glycerol, contrary to the findings of other studies. This has been attributed to configuration of their reactor. They also observed almost complete glycerol conversion to gaseous compounds at 650°C [30]. As complete conversion to gaseous products is not achieved over our RuMgAl catalyst at 600°C, besides of the catalyst characteristics and the reaction conditions, the reactor configuration may play a role; some of the oxygenates produced from the thermal decomposition of glycerol may be more stable under reaction conditions. 3.3 Characteristics of used catalysts and estimation of carbonaceous deposits XRD patterns of the spent RuAl samples (Fig. 8 A) reveal sintering of the ruthenium phase under reaction conditions, as ruthenium reflection peaks are more sharp and intense, compared to those of the fresh sample. Indeed, the calculated average size of Ru particles increases with reaction temperature (Table 2). The characteristic peak of graphitic carbon is not observed at any temperature, indicating that either its amount is very low and not detectable by XRD or carbon is not of graphitic type. For the RuBAl catalyst, no significant alterations are observed after exposure to reaction conditions and no graphitic carbon peak is present either (Fig. 8 Β). The particle size remains the same at all temperatures (Table 2). This is in accordance with previous studies which showed the stabilizing effect of B2O3 in Ni/B2O3-Al2O3 catalysts when the metal is added by co-precipitation in the same synthesis step [18,34]. For RuMgAl, XRD analysis shows that MgAl2O4 spinel is stable but characteristic ruthenium peaks are sharper and more intense in the used samples (Fig. 8 C), indicating sintering of the metallic phase (Table 2). Similar to RuAl and RuBAl catalysts, there are no peaks of graphitic carbon at any temperature. The sintering of Ru particles is not unusual, especially under steam and high reaction temperatures although some supports may moderate the effect [52,54]. According to Gallo et al. [30], the presence of MgO in a RuMgAl catalyst should stabilize the metal particles and prevent sintering during time-on-stream, which does not seem to be the case here. It should be noted, however, that the ruthenium content was only 0.6wt% in their catalyst [30]. Quantitative analysis of carbonaceous deposits was performed by TPH followed by TPO. Carbon which can be removed by hydrogenation during TPH is considered as resilient carbon. TPH profiles obtained for the catalysts after reaction at 400°C for 3h are shown in Fig. 9 A. All catalysts form the same type of carbon, removed at the same temperature. Nevertheless, the amount of methane produced is different, following the order RuMgAl< RuBAl < RuAl. TPO is applied to gasify more refractory carbon from catalysts that have been already submitted to TPH. TPO profiles, presented in Fig. 9 B, reveal that this type of carbon forms on all catalysts, and can be removed at the same temperature from RuAl and RuBAl. However, the amount of refractory carbon formed on RuBAl is higher. This is probably related to glycerol and acrolein polymerization reaction products, which are known to be promoted by acidic surface sites [45,48]. Higher temperatures are needed for the oxidation of coke from RuMgAl (Fig. 9 B). The total amount of carbonaceous deposits (mgC/gcat), estimated by integration of the TPH and TPO profiles, is shown in Table 3 . It is observed that RuAl, which is more active in CC bond cracking, forms less carbon than RuBAl. The lower amount found over RuMgAl at 400°C may be attributed to the fact that this catalyst shows lower activity, regarding both dehydration reactions and CC bonds cleavage. RuAl operating at 500°C accumulates much less carbon compared to the sample after the reaction test at 400°C (Table 3 and Fig. S4). These results are in accordance with the corresponding catalytic performance tests (Fig. 5), which showed almost complete glycerol conversion to gas-phase products and high CO2 yields at 500°C. On the contrary, much more carbon is deposited on RuBAl and RuMgAl catalysts after reaction at 500°C. This is also reasonable as those two catalysts still produce acrolein or acetol at 500°C, i.e., oxygenates that can form carbon deposits. However, the nature of carbonaceous deposits may not be the same, as higher temperatures under TPO conditions are needed for the gasification of coke in the case of RuMgAl (Fig. S4). TPH profiles obtained for the samples after catalytic test at 600°C (Fig. 9 C) show that carbon is hydrogenated to generate CH4 at significantly lower temperatures than in the case of the corresponding samples used at 400°C (Fig. 9 A). This is more pronounced for RuAl catalyst, which still produces higher quantity of carbon easy to hydrogenate (Fig. 9 A, C). Practically all resilient carbon is completely removed up to 650°C, which was not possible for the samples tested at 400°C. In addition, TPO profiles show that lower quantities of refractory carbon are formed on RuAl and RuMgAl samples after catalytic tests at 600°C (Fig. 9 D and Table 3). Obviously, higher reaction temperature and excess of steam in the glycerol reformation feed facilitate carbon gasification at 600°C. However, for RuBAl sample, the amount of carbon removed by TPO is still important. Summarizing, sintering of the metallic phase is observed for all spent catalysts, with Ru particles being more stable on RuBAl. Two types of carbon deposits are formed on the surface of spent catalysts, namely resilient carbon removed by TPH and refractory carbon removed by TPO, Generally, RuAl forms mostly resilient carbon and has a lower coking tendency than the other catalysts, taking also into account its high activity. On the contrary, the largest portion of carbonaceous deposits on the surface of RuBAl can be removed only under oxidizing conditions. In the case of RuMgAl, carbon formation is more complicated and depends on the reaction temperature and the corresponding catalytic behaviour. TPO patterns show an even more stable kind of refractory carbon formed on this catalyst, since higher temperatures are needed for its oxidation. It is noteworthy that no carbon peaks can be detected by XRD. 3.4 Stability assessment The stability of the three catalysts was investigated under lower space time (W/F=0.45mgmin/mL), in order to provoke and detect rapid deactivation. In fact, several space times were explored for the unmodified catalyst before selecting the W/F, for which RuAl catalyst deactivated after a short time on stream. The catalysts remained under reaction conditions at 600°C until their initial activity (estimated from glycerol conversion to gas phase products) dropped to 30%. Results of long-term stability tests are shown in Fig. 10 . RuAl preserves its initial activity for 5h and it takes about 20h for Xgas to drop to 30% (Fig. 10 A). Hydrogen and CO2 yields also decline with the same rate, whereas the rate of the decrease of the CO yield is slower (Fig. 10 B). Stability tests confirm that upon adding MgO to alumina, the acquired RuMgAl catalyst has poorer reforming properties than the unmodified RuAl sample. Under these reaction conditions, the initial value of Xgas is 93% over RuAl and only 34% over RuMgAl. On the other hand, addition of boron does not affect significantly the initial glycerol conversion but enhances notably the rate of RuBAl deactivation, Xgas dropping from 85% to 50% after 5h. To investigate the reasons of deactivation, transmission and scanning electron microscopy were applied after the stability tests. SEM-EDX mapping images verify the poorer ruthenium dispersion on the magnesium-modified catalyst, as compared to RuBAl and RuAl catalysts (Fig. S5). No carbon filaments can be observed on any catalyst sample. TEM images confirm the presence of larger Ru particles in RuMgAl and the absence of filamentous carbon deposits (Fig. 11 ). On the other hand, a platelet like phase is present, which, as revealed by electron diffraction, it is of graphitic type. This type of carbon seems to cover the catalyst surface. Because of its form, small quantities may be sufficient to confine active sites on both, metal particles and the support, leading to rapid deactivation of the catalysts. Because of its low content, it could not be detected by XRD analysis. In line with our observation, Gallo et al. [30] reported coating and deactivation of their RuMgAl catalyst by a very small amount of carbon, which was detectable only with Raman spectroscopy. It is worth discussing the differences in the nature and characteristics of carbon deposits formed over the present catalysts with those of Ni-based catalysts, which produce filamentous carbon under the same reaction conditions [18]. Carbon has a high solubility in the nickel lattice. According to a widely accepted theory [55 and references therein], carbon species (carbon atoms and/or groups of atoms) created on Ni particles can either remain on the surface or diffuse in the subsurface toward graphene growth centers at nickel–support boundaries [55]. There, these carbon species are incorporated into the graphene layer that starts to grow. As the graphene layer develops, it may detach the nickel particle from the support, forming filamentous carbon (whiskers), nanofiber and/or nanotubes of carbon with the nickel particle at the top edge and still available for the reaction. In many Ni-based catalytic systems used in reforming reactions, the formation of filamentous carbon predominates [18,55]. On the other hand, noble metals are known to be more carbon resistant than nickel, especially toward the formation of filamentous carbon. This is ascribed to the fact that the dissolution of carbon into the lattices of noble metals proceeds to a much smaller extent, leaving carbon species at the surface of the metal, where it can react and be removed as CO or CO2 [55 and references therein]. However, although this is benign in the reformation of smaller or more reactive molecules, it seems that it does not solve the problem of deactivation in the present case. TPO profile of RuAl after stability tests (Fig. 12 ) is similar in shape but of higher intensity and shifted to higher temperatures, compared to the corresponding obtained after 3h on stream at 600°C (Fig. 9), indicating the formation of higher amount of less reactive carbonaceous deposits during the stability tests (Table 3). This applies also for RuBAl, which, in addition, presents a second peak (Fig. 12). Comparing the TPO profile obtained for RuMgAl after stability assessment (Fig. 12) with that after catalytic test at 600°C for 3h (Fig. 9), it can be seen that the shape and the temperature at which it evolves remain the same. However, a higher amount of carbon is formed over RuMgAl during stability tests (Table 3). 4 Conclusions Glycerol steam reforming was investigated over Ru-based catalysts, supported on Al2O3, MgO-Al2O3 and B2O3-Al2O3. At low reaction temperatures, the support affects the catalytic performance, whereas at higher temperatures metal activity dominates. Thus, in the support-controlled regime oxygenated products are obtained, the nature of the support playing a key role in selectivity. At higher temperatures, when the dispersed metal takes over, H2 and CO2 are the main reaction products. However, the catalytic performance may be still influenced by the support, i.e the metal-support interface. In other words, metal phase converts intermediate products to H2 and CO2 or CO. The selectivity to these intermediate products varies, depending on the acid-base properties of the support. This approach explains differences observed in the catalytic performance of the three catalysts at 600°C. RuAl is an active catalyst for the title reaction with 92% conversion to gas-phase products and 68% hydrogen yield at 500°C. A comparable activity (85%) and hydrogen yield is achieved over the RuBAl catalyst at a temperature of 600°C. RuMgAl catalyst produces oxygenates and a lesser amount of hydrogen at all studied temperatures. The three Ru-containing catalysts investigated are not very stable with time-on-stream, the main reason being the accumulation of carbonaceous deposits. Graphitic carbon is formed on the surface of all catalysts. This carbon is not in the shape of filaments but it is platelet-like and it seems to have encapsulating properties. The RuAl is more carbon-resistant, compared to the more acidic RuBAl, although both catalysts have comparable catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol, a by-product of biodiesel industry, could be utilized for the production of hydrogen via steam reforming. In the present work, three Ru-based catalysts, namely Ru/Al2O3, Ru/Β2Ο3-Al2O3 and Ru/MgO-Al2O3, have been studied regarding their physicochemical and catalytic properties for the title reaction. N2 adsorption-desorption, powder XRD, CO Adsorption, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, TPR, TEM and SEM-EDS were employed to investigate the textural and structural characteristics of the catalysts. Quantitative assessment of the carbonaceous deposits, formed under reaction conditions, was performed using TPH and TPO methods The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts for the glycerol steam reforming reaction has been investigated in a fixed bed plug flow reactor using a feed of water/glycerol at a molar ratio of 20:1 at 400, 500 and 600°C. Results show that at the low reaction temperature (400°C), the support has a determining role on the catalytic performance, the selectivity to various oxygenates depending on the acid-base properties of the catalyst. At higher temperature (600°C) metal activity dominates, H2 and CO2 being the main reaction products.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerol steam reforming over modified Ru/Al2O3 catalysts
